results.title: At Wells Fargo, a Quest to Increase Diversity Leads to Fake Job Interviews
results.abstract: Black and female candidates are sometimes interviewed after the recipient of a job is identified, current and former employees say.

results.title: The Enduring Afterlife of a Mass Shooting’s Livestream Online
results.abstract: Dozens of recordings of a 2019 massacre in Christchurch, New Zealand, remain online, in a sobering reminder of the internet’s permanence.
results.byline: By Ryan Mac, Kellen Browning and Sheera Frenkel

multimedia.caption: A memorial outside a Tops Friendly Market in Buffalo, N.Y., last weekend after a mass shooting. The gunman took inspiration from a 2019 rampage in Christchurch, New Zealand, videos of which continue circulating.
multimedia.copyright: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times

results.title: ‘I Had to Go Back’: Over 55, and Not Retired After All
results.abstract: After leaving the labor force in unusual numbers early in the pandemic, Americans approaching retirement age are back on the job at previous levels.

multimedia.caption: Kim Williams, 62, lost her job early in the pandemic but has recently gone back to work. “I’m too young to retire, so I had to go back,” she said.

results.title: Chinese Hackers Tried to Steal Russian Defense Data, Report Says
results.abstract: The campaign detailed by a cybersecurity firm highlights Beijing’s increasingly sophisticated tactics to spy on an array of targets, including countries it considers friends.

results.title: In Russia, as Prices Soar, the Outlook for Its Economy Grows ‘Especially Gloomy’
results.abstract: The government has brought stability for now through extreme measures, but forecasters are expecting continued severe inflation and a deep downturn.
results.byline: By Patricia Cohen and Valeriya Safronova

multimedia.caption: Manezhnaya Square in central Moscow on Monday. The Central Bank of Russia has predicted inflation will run between 18 and 23 percent this year.

results.title: Amateur Investors Rode the Bull Up. Now the Bear Looms.
results.abstract: An estimated 20 million people started trading on their own during the pandemic. Some are shifting strategies as stocks tumble, while others are getting out.

results.abstract: A new study reports that nearly half of the homes in the United States were considered “equity-rich” in early 2022.

results.title: How a Trash-Talking Crypto Founder Caused a $40 Billion Crash
results.abstract: Do Kwon, a South Korean entrepreneur, hyped the Luna and TerraUSD cryptocurrencies. Their failures have devastated some traders, though not the investment firms that cashed out early.
results.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Erin Griffith

multimedia.caption: Do Kwon, a founder and chief executive of Terraform Labs, at the company’s offices in Seoul last month. Terraform Labs created the cryptocurrencies Luna and TerraUSD, which collapsed spectacularly last week.

results.title: Family Dollar to Close Warehouse After Rodent Infestation

results.title: Another California board diversity law was struck down, but it already had a big impact.
results.abstract: After California introduced a law requiring public companies to add at least one female director, the share of companies in the state without women on their boards fell to 1 percent.

results.title: Global stocks fall, with the S&P 500 nearing bear market territory.
results.abstract: The S&P 500 was down 0.5 percent in midday trading after falling 4 percent on Wednesday. Stocks in Europe were also sharply lower.
results.byline: By Eshe Nelson and Coral Murphy Marcos

results.title: Fentanyl Tainted Pills Bought on Social Media Cause Youth Drug Deaths to Soar
results.abstract: Teenagers and young adults are turning to Snapchat, TikTok and other social media apps to find Percocet, Xanax and other pills. The vast majority are laced with deadly doses of fentanyl, police say.

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Dillender, left, and her daughter, Kristin, at home in Texas. In December, Ms. Dillender’s son, Kade Webb, bought counterfeit Percocet through a dealer on Snapchat and died of fentanyl poisoning.
multimedia.copyright: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: Elizabeth Dillender, left, and her daughter, Kristin, at home in Texas. In December, Ms. Dillender’s son, Kade Webb, bought counterfeit Percocet through a dealer on Snapchat and died of fentanyl poisoning.

results.title: A federal appeals court says the S.E.C.’s use of an in-house judge violates defendants’ rights.
results.abstract: The ruling by an appeals court covering Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi applies only in that territory, but it’s the latest challenge to the way the agency handles enforcement actions.

results.title: Over 75 Percent of Long Covid Patients Were Not Hospitalized for Initial Illness, Study Finds
results.abstract: Researchers analyzed the largest database of private insurance claims in the United States in the first four months after a diagnostic code for long Covid was created.

results.title: Stocks resume their rout as falling profits reignite fears of inflation.
results.abstract: Target reported that inflation was taking a toll on its bottom line, a day after Walmart reported the same.
